trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of web-based loving-kindness meditation and light exercise on wellbeing
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Internet-based randomised controlled trial comparing the effect of Loving-kindness meditation (LKM) or light exercise on wellbeing and helping behaviour in UK residents

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of normal psychology, cognitive function and behaviour

interventions.interventions: Participants will receive web-based Loving-kindness meditation training. The course is free of charge and very easy to follow. It takes the form of an interactive learning website with instructional videos that can be accessed through a standard web browser. The course requires that 5 x 10 minute sessions are completed per week over the 1 month (4 week) intervention period.
interventions.comparator: Participants will receive web-based light exercise training. The course is free of charge and very easy to follow. It takes the form of an interactive learning website with instructional videos that can be accessed through a standard web browser. The course requires that 5 x 10 minute sessions are completed per week over the 1 month (4 week) intervention period.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Depression, anxiety and irritability (Irritability, depression and anxiety scale)

Helping behaviour (A sum of 10 GBP will be offered to the first 200 participants after the completion of the training and the post-intervention questionnaires. A choice will be given as to whether to receive the full amount in the form of Amazon vouchers or to donate all or half to a charity of their choice)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. UK resident. 2. Fluent English speaker. 3. Aged 18+. 4. Access to internet at home or at a place where personal activities can be developed without being disturbed. 5. Able to operate a PC unaided.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Having been instructed by GP to avoid regular physical activity.

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomization by computerised sequence generation.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: We are interested in comparing two different activities that aim to help people improve their quality of life. We want to use the information collected by this study to clarify the real effectiveness of these activities. In the long run this can help to develop more effective health policies.
